children: A 42-year-old man with a long history of rheumatoid arthritis is incidentally found to have multiple nodules on chest radiography. He is asymptomatic.
Chest CT
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The findings on this patient's chest CT scan are consistent with pulmonary rheumatoid nodules. Rheumatoid nodules in the lung histologically resemble rheumatoid nodules occurring elsewhere. As seen in this image, rheumatoid nodules in the lung are typically located in subpleural areas or near interlobular septa. They may be solitary or multiple, and either solid or cavitary. Although usually asymptomatic, in some patients they may lead to complications, such as pneumothorax, bronchopleural fistula, and hemoptysis.

objective.__html: Identify pulmonary nodules associated with rheumatoid arthritis on chest CT.

children: A 70-year-old man is evaluated for left groin pain with walking.
A radiograph of the hips is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is osteoarthritis. This patient's radiograph shows typical indications of osteoarthritis, including asymmetric joint-space narrowing of the left hip (with narrowing worse in the superior aspect of the joint), mild subchondral sclerosis, subchondral cysts, and small osteophytes.

A 29-year-old man returns for evaluation of recurrent painful oral ulcers, knee pain, and fever. He was diagnosed with his second episode of uveitis 1 week ago. For diagnostic purposes, his arm was pricked with a sterile needle 48 hours ago; the results are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Behçet syndrome, an inflammatory systemic disease associated with pathergy (an inflammatory response, such as a papule, to skin prick with a sterile needle). Behçet syndrome is characterized by recurrent, painful oral and genital mucosal ulcerations, inflammatory eye disease (panuveitis, retinal vasculitis), and pathergy.
A 43-year-old man with psoriatic spondylitis develops slight pain in the toes of the left foot.
Findings of the feet are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the toe findings?

The most likely diagnosis is dactylitis, which manifests as swelling of one or more entire digits and arises from inflammation of the flexor tendon and adjacent soft tissue. In this image, dactylitis is most prominent in the left great and second toes. Dactylitis (sometimes called sausage digits) is commonly seen with spondyloarthritis, especially psoriatic arthritis, as well as with sarcoidosis, gout, tuberculosis, syphilis, and sickle cell disease.
A 64-year-old man is evaluated for chronic left knee pain that worsens with use.
A radiograph of the knee is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient's knee radiograph shows typical changes of advanced osteoarthritis with severe medial joint-space narrowing; there is almost bone-on-bone contact with subchondral sclerosis. Mild medial osteophyte formation and an osteochondral lesion in the medial femoral condyle are also present.
A 66-year-old man is hospitalized for progressive dyspnea and recent onset of hemoptysis. He also has evidence of acute kidney injury.
A chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which is the most common ANCA-associated vasculitis. GPA affects the upper and lower airways, kidneys, eyes, and ears. Pulmonary manifestations of GPA may include nodules, patchy or diffuse opacities, and hilar adenopathy. This patient's radiograph,
shown
below, demonstrates multiple pulmonary nodules (
black arrows
) and fluffy infiltrates (
white arrows
) that are compatible with the diagnosis of GPA.
A 76-year-old man is evaluated for a 10-year history of progressive pain and stiffness in the mid and lower spine. He also has difficulty bending.
A radiograph of the lumbar spine is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis is seen on this patient's radiograph. Although this condition most commonly involves the thoracic spine, the cervical and lumbar spine can also be affected. Radiographic findings in the thoracic spine include distinctive, flowing, linear calcifications and ossifications along the anterolateral aspects of the vertebral bodies, which continue across the disk space. In the cervical spine, hyperostosis occurs initially on the anterior surface of the vertebral body, particularly the inferior lip of the vertebra, resulting in a downward-pointing spur. The findings in the lumbar spine are similar to those in the cervical spine except that the spurs tend to point upward (
arrows
), as
shown
in this patient's radiograph. Complete "bridging" of the lumbar disk space by bone occurs infrequently.
A 73-year-old woman is evaluated for a 3-week history of proximal muscle weakness.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Typical cutaneous involvement of dermatomyositis is the Gottron rash (Gottron papules and Gottron sign), consisting of erythematous to slightly elevated, slightly scaly, violaceous papules and plaques over the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints, as seen in this patient. These findings may also be found overlying the elbows, knees, and/or feet. This type of cutaneous involvement of dermatomyositis can be virtually pathognomonic.
A 47-year-old woman is evaluated for an 18-month history of dry eyes, dry mouth, and a change in the shape of her face, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Sjögren syndrome. This patient has parotid gland enlargement that is beginning to obscure her ears on frontal view. Nearly 50% of patients with Sjögren syndrome develop symmetric salivary gland enlargement that is most obvious in the parotid glands but may also involve the submandibular glands.

objective.__html: Diagnose parotid and salivary gland swelling associated with Sjögren syndrome.

children: A 57-year-old man is evaluated for pain in his fingers and toes. Nail pitting is noted.
A close-up radiographic view of the left metatarsophalangeal joints is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This radiograph shows findings consistent with psoriatic arthritis, including the simultaneous erosive changes and lysis of the terminal phalanges with periostitis and new bone formation, often within the same joint. This frequently leads to ankylosis and gross destruction of isolated joints. When advanced, these changes may cause the characteristic pencil-in-cup appearance of some joints associated with psoriatic arthritis, as
shown
in the radiograph of this patient's hand.

objective.__html: Identify the radiographic findings of psoriatic arthritis.

children: A 43-year-old woman is evaluated for changes in
her hands
. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease and Raynaud phenomenon.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is systemic sclerosis. The finding shown is sclerodactyly, which is most commonly associated with systemic sclerosis. Sclerodactyly is a localized thickening and tightness of the skin of the fingers or toes. The skin appears shiny, tight, and closely adherent. Sclerodactyly is frequently associated with atrophy of the underlying soft tissues.

objective.__html: Diagnose sclerodactyly and its association with systemic sclerosis.

children: A 63-year-old woman is evaluated for chronic painful arthritis.
Hand findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is tophaceous gout, visible as stone-like deforming nodular deposits of urate crystals in the connective tissue (gouty tophi). Tophi are solid chalky white masses of uric acid, surrounded by inflammatory cells and a rind of fibrous tissue. They are located around joints and in soft tissues, with a predilection for the extensor surfaces of the elbows, distal Achilles tendon, fingers (usually from the proximal interphalangeal joints distally), and cartilaginous portions of the ears. Their size ranges from millimeters to several centimeters in diameter. Tophi are deforming, can interfere with function, and directly erode bone. Erosive deposits can be detected on radiography. Ulceration of overlying skin can occur, and accompanying infection can be difficult to treat because tophi are avascular. In the image of this patient's hand, bandages cover draining tophi.
A 50-year-old woman experiences temperature-dependent episodic finger pain. She has no other medical problems.
Hand findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is primary Raynaud phenomenon. The hands are the most likely sites for the attacks of vasospasm that characterize Raynaud phenomenon. A typical episode is precipitated by cold exposure, which is soon followed by distinctive color changes of white (ischemic phase) or blue (cyanotic phase). With rewarming, there is the onset of redness, which heralds reperfusion.
A 57-year-old woman is evaluated for symmetric polyarthritis involving the small joints of the hands.
Findings on the dorsum of the hand are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Rheumatoid arthritis is most compatible with symmetric polyarthritis involving the small joint of the hands along with rheumatoid nodules and ulnar deviation, as shown in this patient. Rheumatoid nodules are subcutaneous growths over bony prominences, extensor surfaces, or juxta-articular regions; they occur in about one third of patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Most nodules are asymptomatic, but they can be painful and interfere with function. Although rheumatoid nodules might be mistaken for gouty tophi, gout much less commonly presents as symmetric, small-joint polyarthritis.
A 31-year-old woman is evaluated for an 8-month history of malaise, fatigue, and subjective fever, as well as the recent onset of bilateral upper arm claudication.
An aortic angiogram is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Takayasu arteritis (TA). TA causes inflammation of the large vessels, most commonly the aorta, followed by the subclavian, common carotid, and renal arteries; the pulmonary arteries may also be involved. This patient's
aortic angiogram
demonstrates high-grade stenosis of the proximal right subclavian artery (
white arrow
) as well as the left subclavian artery just below the origin of the left vertebral artery (
black arrow

). Incidentally noted is anatomic variation with a common origin of the right brachiocephalic artery and the left common carotid artery. TA manifestations include carotidynia, limb claudication, reduced pulses, bruits, and blood pressure discrepancies between the arms.
A 47-year-old man is evaluated for a painful lesion on the
tip of his finger
. He also has Raynaud phenomenon.
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely associated with this finding?

Systemic sclerosis is most likely associated with the digital lesion shown in this image, which demonstrates hyperkeratosis and ulceration of the tip of the third digit. Digital pitting and ulceration of fingertips typically reflects ischemic injury secondary to Raynaud phenomenon. It rarely occurs in primary (idiopathic) Raynaud disease but commonly occurs in patients with secondary Raynaud phenomenon, including systemic sclerosis.

objective.__html: Diagnose digital ulceration due to systemic sclerosis.

children: A 40-year-old woman is evaluated for a skin rash and arthralgia temporally related to intense sunlight exposure. She takes hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for these skin findings?

The most likely diagnosis for the rash shown is subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (SCLE), which is characterized by annular or papulosquamous (psoriasis-like) lesions that are typically light induced. The annular lesions are bright red with central clearing, as seen in this patient. The papulosquamous lesions are bright red plaques with sharp borders and fine scaling. SCLE may be associated with medications (such as hydrochlorothiazide, calcium channel blockers, ACE inhibitors, and terbinafine); with some of the less serious systemic lupus erythematosus manifestations (arthralgia, photosensitivity, serositis); and with anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB antibodies.

A 26-year-old man is evaluated for arthritis involving the left knee, right ankle, and right wrist that developed 3 weeks after an episode of diarrhea. He then developed a rash limited to his palms, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is reactive arthritis. This patient's rash is consistent with keratoderma blennorrhagicum (psoriasiform rash on palms, toes, and soles of the feet), associated with reactive arthritis. Reactive arthritis is a rare cause of inflammatory arthritis that can occur following specific genitourinary and gastrointestinal infections, including
Chlamydia trachomatis
and
Ureaplasma urealyticum
in the urethra and
Campylobacter
Escherichia coli
Salmonella
Shigella
, and
Yersinia

in the intestine. Symptoms of inflammatory arthritis typically appear 2 to 3 weeks after infection. Arthritis is asymmetric and may be monoarticular or oligoarticular; joints commonly affected include the wrist, knee, and ankle. In addition to keratoderma blennorrhagicum, other extra-articular manifestations may include conjunctivitis (more common than anterior uveitis) and circinate balanitis (psoriasiform rash on penis).
A 76-year-old woman has chronic pain in both thumbs.
The left thumb is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is osteoarthritis. This patient demonstrates the characteristic prominence and squaring of osteoarthritis involving the thumb base due to osteophyte formation and subluxation at the first carpometacarpal joint. The joints most commonly involved in osteoarthritis are weight-bearing joints. Affected non–weight-bearing joints in the hand typically include the first carpometacarpal, distal interphalangeal (DIP), and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Findings on physical examination typically include bony enlargement and malalignment. Heberden and/or Bouchard nodes (ossified growths at the medial and dorsolateral aspects of the DIP or PIP joints, respectively) may be present.
A 26-year-old man is evaluated for the acute eruption of the palpable lesions
shown
Which of the following is most compatible with the findings shown?

The most likely diagnosis is immune complex–mediated vasculitis. Although any tissue or organ may be affected, the classic finding is invariably in the skin, as seen in this patient. Immune complexes form from cross-linking of multiple antigens and antibodies. If not cleared, immune complexes deposit in tissue, leading to complement and neutrophil activation with inflammation and tissue damage. Inflammation and erythrocyte extravasation from involved vessels result in nonblanching palpable purpura, usually in dependent areas.
A 52-year-old man is evaluated for chronic pain in the joints of the hands, ankles, and toes.
A radiograph of the hand is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient's plain radiographic findings are consistent with a diagnosis of gout. The radiograph shows periarticular bony erosions, appearing as punched-out bone lesions with disruption of bone cortex (overhanging edges), representing areas of tophaceous monosodium uric acid deposition and accompanying inflammation in a patient with severe, long-standing, inadequately treated gout.

objective.__html: Identify the radiographic findings of gout.

children: A 26-year-old man is evaluated for pain in the low back and buttocks that awakens him at night.
Radiographs of the sacroiliac joints and lumbar spine are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is ankylosing spondylitis. The initial radiographic findings include irregularities along the margins of the sacroiliac joints, leading to eventual ankylosis and fusion. Inflammation of the ligamentous attachments erodes the corners of the vertebral bodies, which produces a squared-off appearance
arrow
. Syndesmophytes (
arrowheads

) represent bony growth of spinal ligaments. Over time, ossification of these ligaments leads to the development of a rigid “bamboo spine,” named because the shape of the vertebrae resembles bamboo on radiography.
A 29-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of symmetric small-joint pain and morning stiffness that lasts 90 minutes.
Hand findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is rheumatoid arthritis, a symmetric polyarthritis that involves the small joints of the hands and feet and other joints throughout the body. This patient has swelling of the third and fourth proximal interphalangeal joints. The classic presentation for rheumatoid arthritis of the hand is symmetric involvement of the metacarpophalangeal joints and proximal interphalangeal joints.
A 30-year-old man is evaluated for recurrent inflammatory eye disease, oral ulcers, and painful scrotal findings, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Behçet syndrome, characterized by recurrent, painful aphthous oral ulcers and at least two of the following features: recurrent genital ulcers, inflammatory eye disease, cutaneous lesions, or positive findings on a pathergy test (development of an erythematous papular or pustular lesion >2 mm occurring within 48 hours after skin prick by a needle).
A 29-year-old woman has a 2-week history of fever, bilateral ankle pain, and painful skin lesions, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's skin lesions?

The most likely diagnosis for this patient's skin lesions is erythema nodosum. The typical clinical presentation of erythema nodosum is the sudden onset of one or more tender, erythematous nodules on the anterior legs that are typically more easily palpated than visualized. The eruption is often preceded by a prodrome of fever, malaise, and/or arthralgia. This patient has Löfgren syndrome, a sarcoidosis triad of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, erythema nodosum, and migratory, symmetric polyarthralgia (often beginning with the ankles); fever is frequently present. When all three parts of the triad are present, there is a 95% diagnostic specificity for sarcoidosis, obviating the need for biopsy.
A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for acute left knee pain.
A radiograph of the left knee is
shown
Which of the following diagnosis is suggested by these findings?

Acute calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) deposition disease (pseudogout) is suggested by the history of acute monoarticular arthritis and radiographic findings showing CPP deposition in the cartilage of the left knee. Radiographic evidence of cartilage calcification, as seen in this elderly patient, is suggestive but not diagnostic of acute CPP crystal arthritis. Acute CPP crystal arthritis (pseudogout) typically presents as a monoarticular inflammatory arthritis, characterized by sudden onset of swelling, pain, loss of function, tenderness, and warmth of the affected joint, usually a knee or wrist. Definitive diagnosis requires identification of CPP crystals (and leukocytes) in synovial fluid.

objective.__html: Diagnose acute calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease.

children: A 49-year-old man with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, Raynaud phenomenon, and gastroesophageal reflux disease has the skin findings
shown
below.
Which of the following is a possible additional diagnosis?

This patient has manifestations of calcinosis cutis, and the most likely additional diagnosis is CREST (calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia) syndrome. Calcinosis occurs in approximately 25% of patients with systemic sclerosis. Present in the hands, forearms, elbows (as in this patient), gluteal region, and iliac crest, these deposits can be seen and/or felt and are easily detected on a radiograph. Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis is most commonly associated with pulmonary arterial hypertension and CREST syndrome. Knowledge of the patient history is often sufficient to distinguish calcinosis cutis from other nodular skin diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis and tophi.

objective.__html: Diagnose calcinosis cutis associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

children: A 42-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of bilateral hand arthritis.
A radiograph of the left hand is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has rheumatoid arthritis, as demonstrated by the radiographic findings of symmetric joint-space narrowing, periarticular osteopenia, and erosive changes most prominent in the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints where the synovium inserts on bone.

objective.__html: Recognize the classic radiographic findings of rheumatoid arthritis.

children: A 55-year-old man is evaluated for the recent onset of muscle weakness and facial rash.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is dermatomyositis. This patient's rash is typical of the heliotrope eruption of dermatomyositis, which consists of a violaceous to dusky erythematous rash with or without edema in a symmetric distribution involving periorbital skin. Sometimes this rash is quite subtle and may cause only a mild discoloration along the eyelid margin. In some cases, massive edema may be present.

objective.__html: Diagnose the heliotrope rash associated with dermatomyositis.

children: A 45-year-old man with a history of rheumatoid arthritis is evaluated for fever and left hip pain that has become progressively severe over the past 6 weeks.
A radiograph of the hip is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has septic arthritis. The radiograph shows cortical destruction on the acetabular and femoral sides of the joint caused by septic arthritis of the hip. In septic arthritis, radiographs of the infected joint may show periarticular osteopenia but are usually normal at presentation; however, radiographs should be obtained in all patients to identify evidence of associated osteomyelitis or concurrent arthritis. Obtaining a baseline radiograph may also be useful for monitoring the patient's response to therapy.
A 29-year-old woman is evaluated for skin lesions on her arms, neck, and scalp.
Representative lesions on her left arm are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus (CCLE) is the most likely diagnosis. This patient has discoid lupus erythematosus, which is the most common variant of CCLE. Discoid lupus consists of slowly progressive, scaly infiltrative papules and plaques or atrophic red plaques (also known as discoid lupus erythematosus) on sun-exposed skin surfaces. Other chronic lesions may be hypertrophic or verrucous appearing.
Most patients with CCLE, particularly those whose lesions are only on the head and neck, do not have systemic disease. Approximately 10% of patients with CCLE develop systemic lupus erythematosus.
